Cell. 1990; 62: 175-185Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (671) Google Scholar). To date, the molecular mechanisms regulating Rb dephosphorylation/phosphorylation are largely unknown. Protein kinase C (PKC) has been implicated as one of the critical components of signaling pathways regulating cell growth. Protein kinase C activation elicits a variety of cellular response by phosphorylating target proteins on serine/threonine residues. Recent studies have demonstrated that specific inhibitors of PKC block cell proliferation supporting a role for PKC in the proliferation pathway (11Carroll M.P. May W.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 1249-1256Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In the present study, we investigated the mechanisms by which ceramide exerts its cellular effects. We show that C6-ceramide indirectly inhibits/inactivates PKCα activity, whereas dihydro-C6-ceramide does not have appreciable effects on PKC activity. Interestingly, C6-ceramide does not inhibit PKC translocation. In addition, we provide evidence that inhibition/inactivation of PKC activity by ceramide may be mediated by protein phosphatases (e.g. CAPP). The implications of these studies on the role of ceramide in signal transduction pathways are discussed. Molt-4 human leukemia cells and Jurkat T cells were purchased from the American Type Culture Collection. RPMI 1640 medium was from Life Technologies, Inc. Fetal bovine serum were obtained from Summit Biotechnology Inc. (Fort Collins, CO). D-Erythro-C6-ceramide, DL-erythrodihydro-C6-ceramide, D-erythro-C2-ceramide, DL-erythrodihydro-C2-ceramide, and sn-1,2-dioleoylglycerol were a kind gift from Dr. Alicja Bielawska (Duke University). Phosphatidylserine and sn-dioctanoylglycerol (DiC8) were purchased from Avanti Polar Lipids Inc. (Alabaster, AL). H7 and staurosporine were from Sigma. Histone H1 was obtained from Calbiochem and Life Technologies, Inc. [γ-32P]ATP and [32P]orthophosphate were from DuPont NEN. PKC isoenzyme-specific antisera have been prepared and characterized previously (12Wetsel W.C. Khan W.A. Merchenthaler I. Rivera H. Halpern A.E. Phung H.M. Negro-Vilar A. Hannun Y.A. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 117: 121-133Crossref PubMed Scopus (389) Google Scholar). Protein A-Sepharose 4B was from Pharmacia Biotech Inc. Cells were maintained in RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum in 5% CO2 at 37°C in a humidified incubator. For treatment, Molt-4 cells and Jurkat T cells in log phase growth were washed once with PBS and seeded at 2 × 105 cells/ml in 2% FBS-supplemented RPMI 1640 medium. To label phosphoproteins, Molt-4 cells were incubated with 150 µCi/ml [32P]orthophosphate (9000 Ci/mmol, DuPont NEN) for 1-2 h in phosphate-free RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% dialyzed FBS and 25 mM HEPES, pH 7.4. Cells were washed once with Tris-buffered saline and seeded at 2 × 105 cells/ml in phosphate-free RPMI 1640 medium containing 2% dialyzed FBS. Following a resting period of 90 min, cells were treated with C6-ceramide (20 µM) for 2 h. In some experiments, the cells were then treated with PMA (0.1 µM) for 20 min. Cells were washed twice with cold Tris-buffered saline and lysed in 1 ml of lysis buffer (150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.5% Deoxycholate, 0.1% SDS, 5 mM EGTA, 10 mM NaF, 5 µg/ml leupeptin, 1 mM sodium orthovanadate, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride). The lysates were cleared by a 10-min centrifugation at 4°C and then incubated with the indicated antibody for 60 min at 4°C. Immunoprecipitates were collected by adsorption to protein A-Sepharose. Protein A-Sepharose beads were washed four times with lysis buffer and followed by one more wash with kinase buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 10 mM NaF, 1 mM Na3VO4, 0.5 mM EDTA, 0.5 mM EGTA, 2 mM MgCl2, 5 µg/ml leupeptin, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride). The beads were boiled in electrophoresis sample buffer and analyzed by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) as described by Laemmli (13Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (204800) Google Scholar). The gels were stained in staining solution (10% acetic acid, 25% isopropanol, 0.03% Coomassie Brilliant Blue), followed by destaining in 10% acetic acid, 10% isopropanol solution. The gels were then dried and exposed to Fuji RX film at −70°C. Following SDS-PAGE, proteins were electrophoretically transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane (14Towbin H. Staehelin T. Gordon J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 4350-4354Crossref PubMed Scopus (44561) Google Scholar). The filter was blocked in 5% dried milk in PBST (0.1% Tween 20 in 1 × PBS), incubated in rabbit antiserum against PKC isoenzymes (1:5000 dilution), followed by horseradish peroxidase-labeled anti-rabbit IgG (1:7500 dilution), washed four times with 1 × PBS, and then developed using the enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL) detection system (Amersham Corp.). Molt-4 cells were treated with 0.1 µM PMA for 20 min at 37°C. Cells were harvested on ice. The cells were washed twice with cold PBS, resuspended in homogenization buffer and sonicated three times for 10 s each, and centrifuged in a TL-100.3 rotor at 40,000 rpm for 40 min. The supernatant (cytosol) was removed and solubilized with an equal volume of 2 × sample buffer. The membrane pellet was resuspended in an equal volume of homogenizing buffer, mixed 1:1 with 2 × sample buffer. Samples were boiled for 5 min and analyzed by Western blot analysis. Protein was measured with bovine serum albumin as the standard by the method of Bradford (15Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (209791) Google Scholar). For determination of kinase activity, immunocomplexes bound to protein A-Sepharose beads described above were washed three times with lysis buffer and then washed two more times with kinase buffer. The beads were resuspended in reaction buffer containing 20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 10 mM MgCl2, 10 µM cold ATP, 0.4 mg/ml histone H1, and 2.5 µCi of [γ-32P]ATP (6000 Ci/mmol, DuPont NEN). In some experiments, purified PKC isoenzymes from baculovirus were used. The concentrations of Ca2+, phosphatidylserine (PS), and dioleoylglycerol (diC18:1) under standard mixed micellar conditions were 1.2 mM, 40 µg/ml, and 3.3 µM, respectively. In some experiments, 10 mM EGTA was used to determine the basal kinase activity. The reaction was started by the addition of [γ-32P]ATP, and incubation was carried out at 30°C for 10 min (with linear kinetics of incorporation during the interval). The reaction was terminated by the addition of equal volume of 2 × sample buffer. Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE on a 10% gel according to the method of Laemmli (13Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (204800) Google Scholar). The gels were stained, and destained before being dried down for autoradiography. Most studies on Rb phosphorylation status have been performed by evaluating the degrees of phosphorylation on shift in mobility of Rb on SDS-PAGE. It has been demonstrated that ceramide induces dephosphorylation of Rb in several cell lines including Molt-4 cells (7Dbaibo G.S. Pushkareva M.Y. Jayadev S. Schwarz J.K. Horowitz J.M. Obeid L.M. Hannun Y.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 1347-1351Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar, 8Venable M.E. Lee J.Y. Smyth M.J. Bielawska A. Obeid L.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 30701-30708Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (367) Google Scholar). In order to establish the effects of ceramide on Rb phosphorylation and to explore the mechanism(s) by which ceramide regulates Rb dephosphorylation, Molt-4 cells were labeled with [32P]orthophosphate and then treated with 20 µM C6-ceramide. Following immunoprecipitation by Rb antibody, the 110-kDa Rb phosphoprotein in Molt-4 cells was detected (Fig. 1). The intensity of the Coomassie Brilliant Blue staining indicated that the amounts of protein loaded in each lane were approximately equal (data not shown). As shown in Fig. 1, C6-ceramide inhibited Rb phosphorylation when compared to the control. These results confirmed the previous results that the effects of ceramide on Rb mobility are due to dephosphorylation. PMA, a potent PKC activator, stimulated the basal phosphorylation of Rb in Molt-4 cells. Pretreatment with ceramide inhibited the PMA-induced phosphorylation of Rb (Fig. 1). These studies demonstrate that activation of PKC results in Rb phosphorylation, and they suggest that one component of induction of Rb dephosphorylation by ceramide may be through inhibition of this PKC-dependent pathway. We next considered if ceramide, added to cells, modulated the activity of PKC. Western blot analysis established that the predominant PKC isozymes expressed in Molt-4 cells were α and βII, with trace amounts of βI, ε, and δ (data not shown). We investigated PKCα in our initial studies. In order to evaluate the status of PKCα“activation” in cells, we developed an immunoprecipitation assay for PKCα. In this assay, the Molt-4 extracts were prepared as described under “Experimental Procedures.” The lysates were immunoprecipitated by PKCα antisera and collected by protein A-Sepharose beads. The calcium-dependent PKCα activity was then assayed using immunoprecipitates in the absence or presence of calcium and lipid activators: PS and diC18:1, using histone H1 as an exogenous substrate. Fig. 2 shows that extracts immunoprecipitated by PKCα antisera contained a basal level of histone H1 kinase activity and this enzyme activity was markedly enhanced in the presence of PS/diC18:1. Sphingosine was able to inhibit both basal and stimulated PKCα activity (Fig. 2). Therefore, results of these experiments showed that PKCα was indeed calcium-dependent and lipid-stimulated, as well as inhibited by sphingosine. To evaluate the effects of C6-ceramide on PKC activity, we treated Molt-4 cells with 10 µM C6-ceramide for 12 h, and the total extracts were prepared and immunoprecipitated by PKCα antisera as before. PKCα activity was then measured in vitro. Fig. 2 shows that the basal and stimulated PKCα activities were dramatically decreased. When sphingosine was added to the kinase reaction mixture, in extracts from cells pretreated with C6-ceramide, it inhibited PKCα activities significantly (Fig. 2). In order to determine whether C6-ceramide specifically inhibited PKCα isoenzyme activity, other existing PKC isoenzymes in Molt-4 cells were examined utilizing the kinase assay as described under “Experimental Procedures.” PKCβII, the other major calcium-dependent isoenzyme present in significant amounts in Molt-4 cells, was also inhibited by C6-ceramide. However, both the basal and stimulated levels of histone H1 kinase activity were approximately 50-fold lower than for PKCα. Other PKC isoenzymes including βI, ε, and δ did not show detectable levels of histone H1 kinase activity (data not shown). Therefore, we carried out our subsequent studies focusing on the PKCα isoenzyme. To further characterize the effects of ceramide on PKCα activity, Molt-4 cells were treated with various concentrations of ceramide for various lengths of time. PKCα inhibition occurred at ceramide concentrations as low as 5 µM, with maximal effects reached at a concentration of 15 µM (Fig. 3A). After 4.5 h of treatment, C6-ceramide (10 µM) significantly diminished calcium-dependent PKCα activity. By 13 h of treatment, both basal and stimulated PKCα activities were almost completely abolished (Fig. 3B). These results show that the inhibition of PKCα activity by ceramide is concentration- and time-dependent. In an attempt to define the specificity of ceramide's effect on PKC inhibition, we compared the effects of equimolar concentrations of several other related lipid molecules. The PKCα activity was markedly inhibited by C6-ceramide and C2-ceramide, whereas the structurally similar C6-dihydroceramide and C2-dihydroceramide were not effective; instead, they appear to slightly stimulate PKC activity. (Fig. 4). Dioctanoylglycerol, DiC8, also had minimal effect on PKCα activity (data not shown). Therefore, the effect of ceramide on inhibition of PKC activity was specific. To demonstrate that the effect of C6-ceramide on PKCα activity was not restricted to Molt-4 cells, we also examined ceramide's effect on PKCα activity using Jurkat T cell line. We found that C6-ceramide exerted a similar effect on PKCα activity in Jurkat cells comparable to Molt-4 cells (Fig. 5). Thus, inhibition of PKCα activity by ceramide observed in Molt-4 cells was not restricted to this cell type. In order to determine the mechanism(s) by which ceramide regulates PKCα activity, we first examined whether C6-ceramide directly affects PKCα activity using an in vitro kinase assay. Purified PKCα from baculovirus was incubated with the kinase reaction mixture including various amounts of C6-ceramide. As shown in Fig. 6A, C6-ceramide had no effect on PKCα activity in vitro as compared to control. This is in contrast to sphingosine, H7, or staurosporine, which inhibited PKCα activity directly (Fig. 6B). Thus, these data indicate that ceramide regulates PKCα activity indirectly. We then examined whether the inhibition of PKCα activity by ceramide was attributed to alteration of PKCα protein. Western blot analysis was carried out on cells treated with ethanol vehicle or 10 µM C6-ceramide using PKCα antisera. Lysates and immunoprecipitated pellets (Fig. 7) from control and ceramide-treated cells had approximately equal amounts of PKCα protein. Therefore, C6-ceramide regulates PKCα activity without altering PKCα protein levels, or the amounts recovered in the immunoprecipitation. To examine whether the effect of ceramide on PKCα is dependent on enzyme translocation, Molt-4 cells were treated with ceramide and followed by PMA stimulation. After 30 min of stimulation by PMA (0.1 µM), membrane and cytosolic fractions were analyzed for PKCα by Western blot. Fig. 8 shows that the addition of PMA caused PKCα translocation in both control and C6-ceramide-treated cells. These data demonstrate that ceramide does not inhibit PKCα translocation but rather inhibits another step required for activation of PKCα. Previous studies have shown that ceramide activates a cytosolic protein phosphatase (CAPP) in vitro (4Dobrowsky R.T. Hannun Y.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 5048-5051Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, it is not clear whether CAPP may mediate the cellular action of ceramide. In an attempt to determine the role of CAPP in ceramide's effect on PKCα activity, we investigated the ability of the phosphatase inhibitor, okadaic acid, to block the effect of ceramide on inhibiting PKCα activity. Molt-4 cells were treated with okadaic acid in the absence and presence of C6-ceramide (10 µM). PKCα activity was measured using histone H1 as the substrate as described under “Experimental Procedures.”Fig. 9 shows that okadaic acid (1-50 nM) enhanced PKCα activity on its own. When Molt-4 cells were treated with okadaic acid and C6-ceramide simultaneously, okadaic acid effectively reversed the effect of C6-ceramide on PKCα inhibition at a concentration as low as 1 nM. The maximal effect of okadaic acid was seen at 10 nM and became less effective when okadaic acid concentration reached 50 nM (Fig. 9). Okadaic acid alone appeared to modestly increase basal and stimulated PKC activity, indicating that inhibition of a phosphatase may be important in PKC regulation. These results also demonstrate that the inhibition of PKCα activity by ceramide is blocked by okadaic acid and may be mediated by a protein phosphatase of the PP2A subfamily, to which CAPP belongs. Since C6-ceramide inhibits PKCα activity, and phosphorylation is an important mode of regulation of PKC activity, we next examined the effects of ceramide on the phosphorylation state of PKCα. Molt-4 cells were labeled with [32P]orthophosphate and then treated with 20 µM C6-ceramide as described under “Experimental Procedures.” The lysates were prepared and immunoprecipitated using PKCα antisera. Subsequent Western blotting revealed the 80-kDa PKCα protein. The intensity of the Coomassie Brilliant Blue staining indicated that the amounts of protein loaded in each lane were approximately equal (data not shown). As shown in Fig. 10, C6-ceramide significantly inhibited PKCα phosphorylation as compared to the control. When Molt-4 cells were stimulated with 0.1 µM PMA for 30 min, PMA enhanced the basal phosphorylation of PKCα, and ceramide was able to inhibit the PMA-induced PKCα phosphorylation (Fig. 10). These results demonstrate that phosphorylation of PKCα may represent a target for ceramide action. Our data show that ceramide inhibits PKCα activity in Molt-4 and Jurkat T cells. The effects of exogenous ceramide are concentration- and time-dependent, and specific in that the closely related dihydroceramide is not effective. Importantly, our results show that ceramide inhibits PKCα activity indirectly. Alteration of PKCα activity is not due to changes in PKCα levels, since control and ceramide-treated cells had approximately equal amounts of PKCα protein as detected by Western blot. These results suggest that PKC is a downstream target of ceramide action. Membrane translocation of PKC has been observed in response to several PKC activators. PKC can participate in signaling pathways through direct translocation from cytosol to membrane, where it is activated by diacylglycerol. Therefore, a potential mechanism by which ceramide inhibits PKC activity is by inhibiting PKC translocation. Our study using Molt-4 cells demonstrates that inhibition of PKCα activity by C6-ceramide is independent of enzyme translocation (Fig. 8). This is in agreement with other studies from our laboratory using HL-60 cells where both PKCα and PKCβII translocation was not inhibited by C6-ceramide. 2M. E. Venable and L. M. Obeid, unpublished results. In contrast to our studies, Jones and Murray demonstrated that ceramide inhibits the translocation of PKCα but not PKCε using mouse epidermal (HEL-37) or human skin fibroblast (SF3155) cells (16Jones M.J. Murray A.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 5007-5013Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar). The translocation of PKCα induced by DiC8 in HEL-37 cells was inhibited by sphingomyelinase treatment or C2-ceramide only in the absence of Triton X-100. The discrepancy between these studies may be due to differences in experimental procedure or may be attributed to different responses of cells used. A major conclusion of our study is that ceramide appears to “inactivate” PKCα. This is supported by the following lines of evidence. First, the effects of ceramide are not a result of direct interaction of ceramide with PKCα. Our in vitro studies show that sphingosine but not C6-ceramide is capable of inhibiting immunoprecipitated PKCα. This supports previous in vitro studies (17Merrill Jr., A.H. Nimkar S. Menaldino D. Hannun Y.A. Loomis C. Bell R.M. Tyagi S.R. Lambeth J.D. Stevens V.L. Hunter R. Liotta D.C. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 3138-3145Crossref PubMed Scopus (227) Google Scholar) that C2-ceramide does not inhibit PKC in vitro. Second, the inhibition of PKCα by ceramide in cells is maintained when PKCα is immunoprecipitated. This suggests that ceramide either causes inactivation of PKCα or it induces the co-immunoprecipitation of an inhibitory protein. The studies on phosphorylation of PKCα support the first possibility, namely that ceramide causes inactivation of PKCα through dephosphorylation. In addition to regulation of protein kinase C by lipids such as phosphatidylserine and diacylglycerol (18Nishizuka Y. Science. 1992; 258: 607-614Crossref PubMed Scopus (4195) Google Scholar, 19Bell R.M. Burns D.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4661-4664Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20Newton A.C. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biomol. Struct. 1993; 22: 1-25Crossref PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar), phosphorylation has emerged as an additional and important mode of regulation for PKC. Protein kinase C is first synthesized as a dephosphorylated, membrane-bound inactive precursor with an apparent molecular mass of 74 kDa. The 80-kDa mature protein is probably formed via post-translational modification such as phosphorylation (21Borner C. Filipuzzi I. Wartmann M. Eppenberger U. Fabbro D. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 13902-13909Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Several recent reports have revealed that phosphorylation at the activation loop activates the enzyme (22Cazaubon S.M. Parker P.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 17559-17563Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Cazaubon S. Bornancin F. Parker P.J. Biochem. J. 1994; 301: 443-448Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar, 24Orr J.W. Newton A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 27715-27718Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Dephosphorylation on PKC's activation loop leads to loss of its activity (24Orr J.W. Newton A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 27715-27718Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A recent study utilizing the catalytic subunits of protein phosphatase 1 (PP1) and 2A (PP2A) to dephosphorylate PKC revealed that PKC is phosphorylated at two different sites (25Dutil E.M. Keranen L.M. DePaoli-Roach A.A. Newton A.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 29359-29362Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). PKC is activated by trans-phosphorylation at the activation loop followed by autophosphorylation at the carboxyl terminus. This finding is consistent with the model that phosphorylation is an important modulator of PKC activity. Previous studies clearly demonstrated that the phosphorylation state of PKC and its subsequent activation is dynamically controlled by a variety of intracellular and extracellular agents. The foregoing results show that C6-ceramide inhibits phosphorylation of PKCα, suggesting that alteration of the phosphorylation state of PKC may be an important mechanism for ceramide action. How does ceramide induce dephosphorylation of PKCα? Previous studies have demonstrated that ceramide activates a cytosolic protein phosphatase (CAPP) in vitro (4Dobrowsky R.T. Hannun Y.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 5048-5051Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). CAPP was found to share several properties with protein phosphatase 2A leading to the hypothesis that ceramide may be a specific lipid activator of PP2A (4Dobrowsky R.T. Hannun Y.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 5048-5051Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). PP2A is a heterotrimeric enzyme consisting of a catalytic (C) subunit and A and B regulatory subunits. The initial studies showed that ceramide activation requires the presence of the B subunit (26Dobrowsky R.T. Kamibayashi C. Mumby M.C. Hannun Y.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15523-15530Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A recent study, however, showed that the A and B′ subunits are not necessary for activation by ceramide (27Law B. Rossie S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 12808-12813Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Therefore, additional subunits may be involved in the ceramide response. One study has shown that okadaic acid, a potent inhibitor of serine/threonine protein phosphatases and CAPP, prevents the effects of C2-ceramide on c-Myc down-regulation in HL-60 cells (5Wolff R.A. Dobrowsky R.T. Bielawska A. Obeid L.M. Hannun Y.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 19605-19609Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In the current study, we found that okadaic acid reverses the action of ceramide on inhibiting PKCα activity (Fig. 9). These studies suggest that the activation of PP2A by ceramide may account for subsequent intracellular events including the inhibition of PKCα. A cell-free kinase-phosphatase preparation from Molt-4 cells would enable us to test the link between ceramide-induced phosphatase activation and subsequent intracellular events. One other issue raised from these studies pertains to the specificity of PKC isoenzyme inhibition by C6-ceramide. The fact that C6-ceramide also inhibits/inactivates PKCβII activity (data not shown) suggests that inhibition/inactivation of PKC by ceramide is not limited to the α isoenzyme and is likely to be mediated by a common mechanism. These studies also raise important implications/suggestions as to the regulation of Rb dephosphorylation by ceramide. Previous studies have shown that Rb functions as a downstream target for ceramide in the regulation of cell growth (7Dbaibo G.S. Pushkareva M.Y. Jayadev S. Schwarz J.K. Horowitz J.M. Obeid L.M. Hannun Y.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 1347-1351Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar). However, the molecular mechanisms by which ceramide induces Rb dephosphorylation are unknown. The results from the present study suggest that one component of dephosphorylation of Rb by ceramide may be through inhibition of PKC. It is also conceivable that ceramide may inhibit/inactivate other (and more direct) Rb kinase such as cyclin/CDK2/4. Studies are under way to evaluate this possibility. Earlier studies have shown that both sphingosine and ceramide share some biologic effects such as inducing Rb dephosphorylation (7Dbaibo G.S. Pushkareva M.Y. Jayadev S. Schwarz J.K. Horowitz J.M. Obeid L.M. Hannun Y.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 1347-1351Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar, 8Venable M.E. Lee J.Y. Smyth M.J. Bielawska A. Obeid L.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 30701-30708Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (367) Google Scholar, 28Chao R. Khan W. Hannun Y.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 23459-23462Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Since sphingosine is a potent and reversible inhibitor of PKC (29Hannun Y.A. Loomis C.R. Merrill Jr., A.H. Bell R.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 12604-12609Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), an important point raised by these studies concerns whether ceramide's effects on inhibiting PKCα activity is dependent on its conversion to sphingosine. Several lines of evidence lead us to conclude that the effects of C6-ceramide on PKC inhibition are independent of sphingosine. First, in previous studies it was shown that C6-ceramide was rapidly taken up by Molt-4 cells, and very little metabolism of C6-ceramide was observed up to 20 h after treatment (7Dbaibo G.S. Pushkareva M.Y. Jayadev S. Schwarz J.K. Horowitz J.M. Obeid L.M. Hannun Y.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 1347-1351Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar). Second, in studies on the effects of serum deprivation on Rb dephosphorylation, it was found that endogenous sphingosine levels did not change significantly after prolonged serum deprivation. Ceramide levels, however, were markedly increased under the same condition. Most importantly, the elevation of ceramide levels correlated with Rb dephosphorylation (7Dbaibo G.S. Pushkareva M.Y. Jayadev S. Schwarz J.K. Horowitz J.M. Obeid L.M. Hannun Y.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 1347-1351Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar). Finally, in vitro studies show that the effects of sphingosine on PKC are reversible and due to competitive inhibition of the regulatory domain (29Hannun Y.A. Loomis C.R. Merrill Jr., A.H. Bell R.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 12604-12609Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). On the other hand, ceramide resulted in dephosphorylation and “irreversible” inhibition of PKCα such that the immunoprecipitated PKC was still inhibited following exposure to ceramide. A final point raised by these studies concerns the mechanisms responsible for ceramide-induced programmed cell death. Ceramide has been demonstrated to be a potent inducer of apoptosis in many cell types including U937 cells (30Obeid L.M. Linardic C.M. Karolak L.A. Hannun Y.A. Science. 1993; 259: 1769-1771Crossref PubMed Scopus (1576) Google Scholar) and HL-60 cells (31Jarvis W.D. Kolesnick R.N. Fornari F.A. Traylor R.S. Gewirtz D.A. Grant S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 73-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (481) Google Scholar). Protein kinase C activators abolish apoptosis (32Tomei L.D. Kanter P. Werner C.E. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1988; 155: 324-331Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar, 33McConkey D.J. Hartzell P. Jondal M. Orrenius S. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 13399-13402Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 34Rajotte D. Haddad P. Haman A. Cragoe E.J. Hoang T. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 9980-9987Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A recent study reported that PKC inhibitors block hyperphosphorylation of BCL2α and lead to apoptosis, whereas PKC activators mediate hyperphosphorylation of BCL2α and suppress apoptosis (35May W.S. Tyler P.G. Ito T. Armstrong D.K. Qatsha K.A. Davidson N.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 26865-26870Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Additional findings from a recent study showed that protein kinase C activation blocks ceramide production and ceramide-induced apoptosis (36Haimovitz-Friedman A. Kan C.C. Ehleiter D. Persaud R.S. McLoughlin M. Fuks Z. Kolesnick R.N. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 180: 525-535Crossref PubMed Scopus (838) Google Scholar). Our present studies provide further evidence for the potential role of PKC in the proliferation and/or the anti-cell death pathways. Blockade of this function by ceramide or other extracellular agents may be a potent inducer of cell death. In summary, ceramide emerges as an important lipid mediator capable of influencing cell growth and apoptosis. In light of the present findings, it is highly likely that PKC is a downstream target in the ceramide growth regulatory pathway. Our results also suggest the existence of cross-talk between the two important lipid-mediated pathways of signal transduction, namely the diacylglycerol/PKC pathway and ceramide/CAPP pathway. We thank Dr. Wasiuddin Khan, Dr. Rick Dobrowsky, and Dr. Gerard Blobe for helpful discussions. We are grateful to Dr. Alicja Bielawska for synthesis of C6-ceramide, C2-ceramide, dihydro-C6-ceramide, and dihydro-C2-ceramide. We also thank Dr. Julie Saba for critical reading of the manuscript and Marsha Haigood for expert secretarial assistance.

Distinct yet overlapping sets of STAT transcription factors are activated by different cytokines. One example is the differential activation of acute phase response factor (APRF, also called Stat3) and Stat1 by interleukin 6 and interferon-γ. Interleukin 6 activates both factors while, at least in human cells, interferon-γ recruits only Stat1. Stat1 activation by interferon-γ is mediated through a cytosolic tyrosine motif, Y440, of the interferon-γ receptor. In an accompanying paper (Gerhartz, C., Heesel, B., Sasse, J., Hemmann, U., Landgraf, C., Schneider-Mergener, J., Horn, F., Heinrich, P. C., and Graeve, L. (1996) J. Biol. Chem. 271, 12991-12998), we demonstrated that two tyrosine motifs within the cytoplasmic part of the interleukin 6 signal transducer gp130 specifically mediate APRF activation while two others can recruit both APRF and Stat1. By expressing a series of Stat1/APRF domain swap mutants in COS-7 cells, we now determined which domains of Stat1 and APRF are involved in the specific recognition of phosphotyrosine motifs. Our data demonstrate that the SH2 domain is the sole determinant of specific STAT factor recruitment. Furthermore, the SH2 domain of Stat1 is able to recognize two unrelated types of phosphotyrosine motifs, one represented by the interferon-γ receptor Y440DKPH peptide, and the other by two gp130 YXPQ motifs. By molecular modeling, we propose three-dimensional model structures of the Stat1 and APRF SH2 domains which allow us to explain the different binding preferences of these factors and to predict amino acids crucial for specific peptide recognition. Today. 1990; 11: 350-354Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (514) Google Scholar). Kerr I.M. Stark G.R. Science. 1994; 264: 1415-1421Crossref PubMed Scopus (5062) Google Scholar). This pathway has first been established for interferon (IFN) signaling. The transcription factors Stat1α, Stat1β, and Stat2, formerly known as p91, p84, and p113 components, respectively, of the IFN-stimulated gene factor-3 complex were shown to be activated by tyrosine phosphorylation in response to IFNα (3Schindler C. Shuai K. Prezioso V.R. Darnell Jr., J.E. Science. 1992; 257: 809-813Crossref PubMed Scopus (727) Google Scholar) and Stat1 also by IFNγ (4Shuai K. Schindler C. Prezioso V.R. Darnell Jr., J.E. Subsequent to their phosphorylation, STAT factors homo- or heterodimerize, translocate to the nucleus, and bind to regulatory DNA elements of target genes. STAT factors contain putative SH3 and SH2 domains in their carboxyl-terminal parts as well as potential leucine zipper-like α-helical structures toward their amino termini (6Fu X.Y. Cell. 1992; 70: 323-335Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (304) Google Scholar). The SH2 domains seem to be involved in both the activation process and the dimerization of the STATs (7Shuai K. Horvath C.M. Huang L.H.T. Qureshi S.A. Cowburn D. Darnell Jr., J.E. Cell. 1994; 76: 821-828Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (687) Google Scholar). Genes & Dev. 1995; 9: 984-994Crossref PubMed Scopus (452) Google Scholar). Cell. 1994; 77: 63-71Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (877) Google Scholar). Furthermore, we have demonstrated that, in addition to APRF(Stat3), Stat1 is also activated in response to IL-6 (16Lütticken C. Wegenka U.M. Yuan J. Buschmann J. Schindler C. Ziemiecki A. Harpur A.G. Wilks A.F. Yasukawa K. Taga T. Kishimoto T. Barbieri G. Pellegrini S. Sendtner M. Heinrich P.C. Horn F. Science. 1994; 263: 89-92Crossref PubMed Scopus (713) Google Scholar). Further insight into the mechanisms of STAT activation originated from our observation that IL-6 induces the transient association of the STATs with the signal transducer gp130 (16Lütticken C. Wegenka U.M. Yuan J. Buschmann J. Schindler C. Ziemiecki A. Harpur A.G. Wilks A.F. Yasukawa K. Taga T. Kishimoto T. Barbieri G. Pellegrini S. Sendtner M. Heinrich P.C. Horn F. Science. 1994; 263: 89-92Crossref PubMed Scopus (713) Google Scholar). This finding suggested that the phosphorylation of STAT factors occurs at the cytokine receptor cytoplasmic parts. In fact, recent data indicate that the activation of Stat1 by IFNγ relies on the interaction of its SH2 domain with a phosphotyrosine motif, Y440DKPH, of the IFNγ receptor α chain (IFNγR) (26Greenlund A.C. Farrar M.A. Viviano B.L. Schreiber R.D. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 1591-1600Crossref PubMed Scopus (376) Google Scholar, 27Greenlund A.C. Morales M.O. Viviano B.L. Yan H. Krolewski J. Schreiber R.D. Immunity. 1995; 2: 677-687Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (252) Google Scholar). Similarly, the activation of IL-4-STAT (STAT6) by IL-4 requires specific phosphotyrosine motifs in the IL-4 receptor α subunit (28Hou J. Schindler U. Henzel W.J. Ho T.C. Brasseur M. McKnight S.L. Science. 1994; 265: 1701-1706Crossref PubMed Scopus (731) Google Scholar). In the case of gp130, Stahl et al. (29Stahl N. Farruggella T.J. Boulton T.G. Zhong Z. Darnell Jr., J.E. Yancopoulos G.D. Science. 1995; 267: 1349-1353Crossref PubMed Scopus (869) Google Scholar) have reported that four tyrosine motifs conforming to the consensus sequence YXXQ are all able to independently mediate APRF(Stat3) activation. Recent studies from our laboratory have demonstrated that two of these YXXQ motifs (Y767RHQ and Y814FKQ) give rise to the specific activation of APRF(Stat3) while the other two (Y905LPQ and Y915MPQ) are capable of mediating the activation of both APRF(Stat3) and Stat1 (56Gerhartz C. Heesel B. Sasse J. Hemmann U. Landgraf C. Schneider-Mergener J. Horn F. Heinrich P.C. Graeve L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; : 12991-12998Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar). The sequences of the latter motifs, however, do not resemble the IFNγR Y440DKPH motif. This raised the question of how Stat1 can be activated through two distinct types of phosphotyrosine motifs. Is the Stat1 SH2 domain able to recognize different motifs on its own or are additional domains of Stat1 involved? By use of a series of Stat1/Stat3 chimeras we now demonstrate that the Stat1 SH2 domain is both required and sufficient to direct the activation through both the IFNγR Y440DKPH motif and the gp130 YXPQ motifs. A domain swap mutant in which the SH2 domain of APRF(Stat3) was replaced by the one of Stat1 exhibited the same activation specificity as wild-type Stat1. This finding demonstrates that solely the SH2 domain defines the interaction of STATs with gp130, and that the SH2 domain of Stat1 is able to interact with distinct types of phosphotyrosine motifs. Furthermore, we present three-dimensional model structures of the Stat1 and APRF(Stat3) SH2 domains which were built by using known SH2 domain structures as templates. Based on these models we are now able to explain the different specificities of the two STAT factors for receptor phosphotyrosine motifs. In addition, these models allow us to predict amino acids within the SH2 domains that are crucial for specific STAT factor/cytokine receptor interactions. SalI sites were introduced 3′ of the stop codons into murine APRF(Stat3) and human Stat1 cDNAs that were cloned into pBluescript (Stratagene) vectors through site-directed mutagenesis (U.S.E. Mutagenesis Kit, Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) generating the plasmids pB-Stat3-Sal and pB-Stat1-Sal, respectively. The pSVL-Stat3 and pSVL-Stat1 expression vectors were then constructed by subcloning the coding sequences into a pSVL vector (Pharmacia) which had been modified by eliminating the unique SalI site in the vector backbone and instead introducing a SalI site into the polylinker region. For the construction of cDNAs coding for Stat1/Stat3 chimeric molecules, additional unique restriction sites were introduced into the STAT cDNAs by site-directed mutagenesis. BamHI sites were introduced into pB-Stat3-Sal and pB-Stat1-Sal changing APRF(Stat3) codons 697-699 into GCG GAT CCA (silent mutation) and Stat1 codons 693-695 into CTG GAT CCC (thereby replacing glycine 695 by proline), respectively. The introduction of an XbaI site into pB-Stat3-Sal changed codons 716-717 to TCT AGA and replaced threonines 716 and 717 by serine and arginine, respectively. The corresponding position in the Stat1 cDNAs (codons 715-716) already carries a unique XbaI site. By using the authentic SphI (codons 324-326 in Stat1 and 328-330 in Stat3), TaqI (Stat3 codons 569-570), and MseI (Stat1 codons 565-566) sites, and the newly introduced BamHI and XbaI sites, chimeric STAT cDNAs were constructed by exchanging the respective DNA fragments within the pBluescript vector context. The cDNAs were then subcloned into pSVL. All constructs were sequenced throughout chimeric and mutated regions. The “R602Q” point mutation in the Stat1 SH2 domain was generated by site-directed mutagenesis (U.S.E. kit, Pharmacia), changing Stat1 codon 602 from CGG (arginine) to CAG (glutamine). COS-7 cells (ATCC CRL 1651) were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 10% fetal calf serum, streptomycin (100 µg/ml), and penicillin (100 IU/ml). Cells were transfected by electroporation with a single pulse at 230 V and 960 µF using a Gene Pulser™ (Bio-Rad). Approximately 2 × 106 cells were cotransfected in 0.8 ml of medium with 10 µg and 20 µg of expression vectors for receptor chimeras and STAT proteins, respectively. After electroporation, the cells were grown to confluency (48 to 72 h) and stimulated by adding human recombinant Epo (7 units/ml) to the medium for 15 min. Heinrich P.C. Horn F. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 276-288Crossref PubMed Scopus (490) Google Scholar) with the following modifications. Chimera Stat3/1 combined the amino-terminal half of Stat3 with the carboxyl-terminal half of Stat1α. In the other chimeras, internal parts of Stat3 were replaced by the respective Stat1 sequences. In Stat3/1[D, SH3 + 2, Y] and Stat3/1[D, SH3 + 2], the DNA-binding, SH3, and SH2 domains in combination with and without the Stat1 tyrosine phosphorylation site, respectively, were from Stat1 while in Stat3/1[SH2] only the Stat3 SH2 domain was replaced by the one of Stat1 (Fig. 1A). The cells were then stimulated by addition of erythropoietin (Epo) to the medium. Cochran B.H. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 4477-4484Crossref PubMed Scopus (554) Google Scholar). Fusion of influenza virus with target membranes is induced by acid and involves complex changes in the viral envelope protein hemagglutinin (HA). In a first, kinetically distinct step, the HA polypeptide chain 2 (HA2) is inserted into the target membrane bilayer. Using hydrophobic photolabeling with the phospholipid analogue 1-O-hexadecanoyl-2-O-[9-[[[2-[125I]iodo-4(trifluoromethyl-3H-diazirin-3-yl)benzyl]oxy]carbonyl]nonanoyl]-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine, we identified the segment within HA2 that interacts with the membrane. The sole part of the HA2 ectodomain that was labeled with the membrane-restricted reagent is the NH2-terminal fusion peptide (residues 1-22). No labeling occurred within the long coiled coil region generated during the acid-induced conformational transition (Bullough, P. A., Hughson, F. M., Skehel, J. J., and Wiley, D. C. (1994) Nature 371, 37-43). These data strongly suggest that the coiled coil region of HA2 does not insert into the lipid bilayer. This conclusion is at variance with the recent suggestion (Yu, Y. G., King, D. S., and Shin, Y.-K. (1994) Science 266, 274-276) that the coiled coil of HA may splay apart and insert into the target membrane, providing a mechanism by which the viral and the target membrane may come in close apposition.

A mutant of Escherichia coli lacking phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) and a monoclonal antibody (mAb 4B1) directed against a conformationally sensitive epitope (4B1) of lactose permease were used to establish a novel role for a phospholipid in the assembly of a membrane protein. Epitope 4B1 is readily detectable in spheroplasts and right-side-out membrane vesicles from PE-containing but not from PE-deficient cells expressing lactose permease. Lactose permease from PE-containing membranes, but not from PE-deficient membranes, subjected to sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS)-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and Western blot analysis is also recognized by mAb 4B1. If total E. coli phospholipids or PE (but not phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylglycerol, or cardiolipin) are blotted on nitrocellulose sheets (Eastern blot) prior to transfer of proteins from SDS-polyacrylamide gels, the permease from PE-deficient cells regains its recognition by mAb 4B1. Therefore, PE is required during assembly to form epitope 4B1, but, once formed, sufficient “conformational memory” is retained in the permease to either retain or reform this epitope in the absence of PE. Lactose permease lacking epitope 4B1 can be induced to form the epitope if partially denatured and then renatured in the presence of PE specifically. These results establish for the first time a role for PE as a molecular chaperone in the assembly of the lactose permease. A mutant of Escherichia coli lacking phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) and a monoclonal antibody (mAb 4B1) directed against a conformationally sensitive epitope (4B1) of lactose permease were used to establish a novel role for a phospholipid in the assembly of a membrane protein. Epitope 4B1 is readily detectable in spheroplasts and right-side-out membrane vesicles from PE-containing but not from PE-deficient cells expressing lactose permease. Lactose permease from PE-containing membranes, but not from PE-deficient membranes, subjected to sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS)-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and Western blot analysis is also recognized by mAb 4B1. If total E. coli phospholipids or PE (but not phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylglycerol, or cardiolipin) are blotted on nitrocellulose sheets (Eastern blot) prior to transfer of proteins from SDS-polyacrylamide gels, the permease from PE-deficient cells regains its recognition by mAb 4B1. Therefore, PE is required during assembly to form epitope 4B1, but, once formed, sufficient “conformational memory” is retained in the permease to either retain or reform this epitope in the absence of PE. Lactose permease lacking epitope 4B1 can be induced to form the epitope if partially denatured and then renatured in the presence of PE specifically. These results establish for the first time a role for PE as a molecular chaperone in the assembly of the lactose permease. Only a limited number of reports address the role of the native phospholipid environment in the function and assembly of membrane proteins. Clearly, the amphipathic environment of the membrane is an important determinant in the folding and maintenance of membrane protein structure. However, what has not been widely considered is a role for individual phospholipids in determining the folding pathway for membrane proteins independent from the maintenance of the final structure, i.e. to act in the capacity of a non-protein molecular chaperone. Mutants of Escherichia coli are available in which membrane phospholipid composition can be varied in a way that is difficult to achieve in vitro (DeChavigny et al., 8.DeChavigny A. Heacock P.N. Dowhan W. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 5323-5332Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar; Dowhan, 10.Dowhan W. Methods Enzymol. 1992; 209: 7-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). Such “phospholipid mutants” were used to study the in vivo role of PE 1The abbreviations used are: PEphosphatidylethanolamineIPTGisopropyl-1-thio-β-D-thiogalactosideRSOright-side-outISOinside-outDTTdithiothreitolmAbmonoclonal antibodypAbpolyclonal antibodyPAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresisPGphosphatidylglycerolCLcardiolipinPCphosphatidylcholinePIPES1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid. in lactose permease (lacY gene product) function (Bogdanov and Dowhan, 2.Bogdanov M. Dowhan W. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 732-739Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar). The lactose permease of E. coli is an extensively studied prototype of most secondary transport systems found in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms (Kaback et al., 1994). PE is not required for energy-independent downhill translocation of substrate mediated by lactose permease, but appears to be essential for H+-coupled active lactose accumulation in vivo (Bogdanov and Dowhan, 1995). These results parallel the earlier observation (Chen and Wilson, 7.Chen C.-C. Wilson T.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 10150-10158Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar; Page et al., 17.Page M.G.P. Rosenbusch J.P. Yamato I. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 15897-15905Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) with purified permease reconstituted into proteoliposomes where PE was also found to be required specifically for active transport. phosphatidylethanolamine isopropyl-1-thio-β-D-thiogalactoside right-side-out inside-out dithiothreitol monoclonal antibody polyclonal antibody polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis phosphatidylglycerol cardiolipin phosphatidylcholine 1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid. How phospholipids affect membrane protein assembly and function is still largely unknown. Do the properties of the target membrane phospholipids affect assembly and function? Do individual phospholipids act as conformational determinants? In the present work, we address the possibility that membrane phospholipid composition, and specifically PE, determines the conformation of the lactose permease. The experiments described here combine structural and functional information on the lactose permease with the use of a conformationally sensitive monoclonal antibody (Sun et al., 21.Sun J. Wu J. Carrasco N. Kaback H.R. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 990-998Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar) directed against an epitope in the periplasmic loop [L(VII/VIII)] of the permease between helices VII and VIII (Fig. 1). Monoclonal antibodies have been used effectively to detect folding intermediates of soluble proteins in solution (Fedorov et al., 11.Fedorov A.N. Friguet B. Djavadi-Ohaniance L. Alakhov Y.B. Goldberg M.E. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 228: 351-358Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar), but have not been used extensively to follow folding of membrane proteins as described in this report. The proper assembly of lactose permease, as assessed by the presence of the conformational epitope, into the membranes of an E. coli mutant lacking PE (DeChavigny et al., 1991) was compared to assembly in wild type cells to establish a requirement for PE. We also introduce a novel adaption of the Western blot procedure termed an “Eastern-Western” in which phospholipids are applied to the surface of nitrocellulose sheets (Taki et al., 22.Taki T. Handa S. Ishikava D. Anal. Biochem. 1994; 221: 312-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar) prior to transfer of proteins from SDS-polyacrylamide gels by electroblotting. This combination of protein and ligand on a solid support allows the monitoring by a conformation-specific monoclonal antibody of the involvement of a specific phospholipid in the refolding of a denatured protein. The information gathered from these approaches indicate that PE plays an important role in facilitating the proper assembly of the lactose permease into the membrane and thereby demonstrates for the first time that a phospholipid can act as a molecular chaperone. E. coli strain AD93 (pss93::kan, PE-deficient) cannot make either PE or phosphatidylserine except when carrying plasmid pDD72 (pss+, PE-containing) (DeChavigny et al., 1991). All strains (mutant and wild type for PE formation) were grown at 30°C in LB medium containing 50 mM MgCl2 and, except as noted, carried multiple copies of the lacY gene on plasmid pT7-5/lacY (Bibi and Kaback, 1.Bibi E. Kaback H.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4325-4329Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar). Ampicillin (100 μg/ml) and IPTG (1 mM) were included in the growth medium to maintain plasmid pT7-5/lacY and induce lactose permease synthesis, respectively. A modification of the protocol of van Veen et al.(24.van Veen H.W. Abee T. Korstee G.J.J. Konings W.N. Zehnder A.J.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 19377-19383Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) was used to make spheroplasts. Midexponential phase cells were suspended in 10 mM potassium PIPES (pH 7.0), 0.75 M sucrose, 10 mM MgSO4, 2.5% (w/v) LiCl, and 50 mg/ml chloramphenicol. After addition of either 1 mg/ml or 0.1 mg/ml lysozyme to pss+ or pss- cells, respectively, cell suspensions were chilled to 2°C, warmed to room temperature, and subsequently incubated with gentle shaking at 30°C for 30 min or 5 min for pss+ cells or pss- cells, respectively. Intact spheroplasts were collected by centrifugation (3,000 × gav for 10 min) at room temperature and resuspended at 10 mg/ml total protein in the above buffer without LiCl. RSO membrane vesicles were made by diluting a pellet of spheroplasts into a 50-fold volume of 10 mM potassium PIPES buffer (pH 7.0). The solution was adjusted to 10 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, and 10 mg/ml deoxyribonuclease and incubated for 10 min on ice. Intact cells and cell debris were removed by centrifugation at 4000 × gav for 5 min, and the supernatant was centrifuged at 30,000 × gav for 30 min at 4°C. Resulting RSO membrane vesicles were suspended to a final concentration of 2 mg of membrane protein/ml in 50 mM potassium PIPES (pH 7.0) containing 10 mM MgCl2. ISO membrane vesicles were prepared as described previously (Bogdanov and Dowhan, 1995) and were resuspended at 10 mg/ml in ice-cold 100 mM potassium HEPES buffer (pH 8.0) containing 125 mM sucrose, 10 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM DTT. Protein concentration was measured using the BCA method as suggested by the supplier (Pierce). Aliquots (0.05 ml) of stock spheroplasts, RSO membrane vesicles, or ISO membrane vesicles were diluted 10-fold into suspension buffer (100 mM potassium HEPES (pH 8.0), 125 mM sucrose, 10 mM MgCl2) containing 5% bovine serum albumin followed by the addition of 5 μl of affinity-purified mAb 4B1 (5 mg/ml). After incubation at room temperature for 45 min, mixtures were centrifuged for 10 min at 10,000 × gav for spheroplasts or 30 min at 30,000 × gav for RSO and ISO membrane vesicles. Pellets were washed twice with suspension buffer containing 5% bovine serum albumin and resuspended in a final volume of 0.5 ml of suspension buffer containing 5% bovine serum albumin. 35S-Protein A (2.5 μl, Amersham) was added and incubation was continued for 45 min. Samples were centrifuged as above, washed sequentially with suspension buffer first containing 5% bovine serum albumin and second without bovine serum albumin, and finally resuspended in suspension buffer without bovine serum albumin to the final protein concentration of 10.5 mg/ml for spheroplasts and 2.3 mg/ml for RSO or ISO membrane vesicles. Aliquots of membrane suspensions were adjusted to the concentration of SDS gel loading buffer (2.8% SDS, 10% glycerol, 100 mM DTT) and heated at 37°C for 15 min prior to being subjected to PAGE in 12.5% gels containing 0.1% SDS. Transfer of proteins from gels to nitrocellulose sheets (Schleicher & Schuell, pore size of 0.45 μm) using a semidry electroblotting system (Milliblot-SDE electroblotting apparatus) and detection by antibody were carried out as described previously (Bogdanov and Dowhan, 1995) except as follows. The gel was incubated for 10 min at room temperature in cathode buffer 1 (electroblotting system) prior to transfer. Bound antibody (mAb 4B1 or pAb) was visualized by either the ECL detection system (Amersham with supplied peroxidase-labeled anti-mouse or anti-rabbit antibody, respectively) and exposure to x-ray film or 35S-protein A and analysis with a Betagene Imager as described previously (Bogdanov and Dowhan, 1995). In the Eastern-Western blot procedure, bands of phospholipids (0.05-0.10 mg) on silica gel thin layer plates were developed using chloroform/methanol/water/30% ammonium hydroxide (120:75:6:2, v/v); for total E. coli phospholipids, no chromatography was performed. Plates were dipped in isopropyl alcohol/0.2% aqueous CaCl2/methanol (40:20:7, v/v) for 20 s. A nitrocellulose sheet was placed on top of the silica gel surface followed by a glass microfiber sheet (Whatman, United Kingdom). Transfer of phospholipid was accomplished by pressing on the stack with a metallic heating block at 130°C for 10 s (modification of Taki et al.(1994)). Western blot transfer (phospholipid side facing the acrylamide gel) of proteins was accomplished as described above. The binding of mAb 4B1 to RSO membrane vesicles and spheroplasts was utilized to determine whether structural differences exist between lactose permease assembled in either PE-deficient or PE-containing membranes. As shown in Fig. 2A, binding of mAb 4B1 to spheroplasts and RSO membrane vesicles from PE-deficient cells is reduced to the level observed for binding to control membranes lacking the permease. High level binding to permease in membranes from PE-containing cells was observed as reported previously (Carrasco et al., 3.Carrasco N. Tahara S.M. Patel L. Goldkorn T. Kaback H.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1982; 79: 6894-6898Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar, 4.Carrasco N. Viitanen P. Herzlinger D. Kaback H.R. Biochemistry. 1984; 23: 3681-3687Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar; Herzlinger et al., 13.Herzlinger D. Viitanen P. Carrasco N. Kaback H.R. Biochemistry. 1984; 23: 3688-3693Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar; Sun et al., 1996). The amount of permease in each membrane preparation was established using Western blot analysis with a site-directed pAb against the C terminus of the permease using either the ECL chemiluminescence-based method (Fig. 2B) or radiolabeled protein A (Fig. 2C) for qualitative or quantitative measurements, respectively. The specific content of permease in spheroplasts (500 and 600 cpm/mg of total membrane protein) and RSO membrane vesicles (6000 and 7000 cpm/mg of membrane protein) was comparable in samples prepared from PE-containing and PE-deficient cells, respectively. Therefore, the marked difference in mAb 4B1 binding to membranes is due specifically to differences in recognition of the epitope. The results are consistent with the hypothesis that membrane phospholipid composition is a determinant for the conformation of lactose permease. Membrane preparations from PE-containing and PE-deficient cells were then analyzed by Western blot analysis, comparing the sensitivity of SDS-denatured permease to detection with mAb 4B1 and pAb (Fig. 3A). As reported previously (Carrasco et al., 1982), mAb 4B1 binds to permease from PE-containing cells after being transferred to a solid support. Permease from PE-deficient cells exhibits greatly reduced binding of mAb 4B1, although probing with pAb verified the presence of ample amounts of permease (Fig. 3B). Therefore, permease assembled in PE-containing membranes retains sufficient “conformational memory” to reform the native structure of the epitope after removal of SDS. The results confirm the absence of the conformational epitope in PE-deficient membranes and also suggest that once the information is imparted to form the epitope in PE-containing cells, PE is no longer required to maintain the epitope. To further investigate the role of phospholipids in the formation of this conformational epitope, the Eastern-Western blot procedure was developed. By combining these two procedures (Fig. 4), denatured proteins are exposed to hydrated phospholipids on the surface of nitrocellulose sheets as they exit the polyacrylamide gel and begin to refold in the absence of SDS. The surprising finding is that lactose permease from PE-deficient membranes subjected to Eastern-Western blotting with either PE or E. coli phospholipids regains the ability to bind mAb 4B1. In marked contrast, neither the E. coli anionic phospholipids PG and CL nor PC, which is also zwitterionic but not present in E. coli, promote the formation of the epitope. This specificity for PE is consistent with the earlier results of Chen and Wilson(1984) who showed that only PE and not the other three phospholipids listed above could restore active transport to lactose permease reconstituted in proteoliposomes. Therefore, restoration of mAb 4B1 binding specifically by PE indicates that PE plays a positive role as a structural determinant, rather than acting to exclude a negative determinant in the form of anionic phospholipids. Subjecting membrane preparations to SDS-PAGE in the presence of 5 M urea eliminates detection by mAb 4B1 in both Western and Eastern-Western blots with permease from both PE-containing and PE-deficient cells (data not shown). Lactose permease retains about 70% of its helical structure in SDS as estimated from circular dichroism measurements, 2D. L. Foster, M. Boublik, and H. R. Kaback, unpublished data. and recent evidence indicates that denaturants such as SDS induce alterations in helical packing within the permease with little or no change in secondary structure (Jung et al., 15.Jung K. Jung H. Kaback H.R. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 3980-3985Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). However, urea disrupts the secondary structure of proteins by stabilizing the random coil state (Schein, 18.Schein C.H. Bio/Technology. 1990; 8: 308-317Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). In the case of the permease, urea appears to eliminate structural elements that either carry conformational memory after assembly in the presence of PE in vivo or have potential to form the 4B1 epitope. The possibility that residual PE is bound to permease from PE-containing cells was eliminated by labeling membrane phospholipids by growth in the presence of 32Pi, followed by SDS-PAGE. Autoradiography of the gel revealed no difference in the labeling pattern between samples from PE-containing cells with or without lactose permease. However, bands in other regions of the gel exhibited significant radioactivity, indicating that the 32Pi was of sufficiently high specific activity to detect low levels of protein-associated radiolabel such as tightly bound PE. Therefore, the 4B1 epitope once formed is maintained even in the absence of PE. Finally, when PE-deficient membranes are solubilized in the presence of PE-containing liposomes (12.5 mg of total membrane protein plus 50 mg of either PE or wild type E. coli phospholipid), no restoration of mAb 4B1 binding is observed (data not shown), indicating that formation of the epitope is dependent on removal of SDS in the presence of PE rather than simply exposure of the denatured protein to PE. The epitope recognized by mAb 4B1 (see Fig. 1) consists of Phe-247, Phe-250, and Gly-254 on one face of a short α-helical segment in the periplasmic loop between helices VII and VIII (Sun et al., 1996). Treatment of RSO membrane vesicles with mAb 4B1 inhibits all reactions catalyzed by the permease that involve net H+ translocation with no effect on ligand binding and either equilibrium exchange or counterflow of substrate (Carrasco et al., 1982, 1984). The “uncoupling” effect of mAb 4B1 is remarkably similar to the effects of site-directed mutations in Glu-325 (helix X) (Carrasco et al., 5.Carrasco N. Antes L.M. Poonian M.S. Kaback H.R. Biochemistry. 1986; 25: 4486-4488Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar, 6.Carrasco N. Puttner I.B. Antes L.M. Lee J.A. Larigan J.D. Lolkema J.S. Roepe P.D. Kaback H.R. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 2533-2539Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar), as well as the functional alterations observed in vivo with mutants devoid of PE (Bogdanov and Dowhan, 1995) and in reconstituted proteoliposomes lacking PE (Page et al., 1988; Seto-Young et al., 20.Seto-Young D. Chen C.-C. Wilson T.H. J. Membr. Biol. 1985; 84: 256-267Crossref Scopus (32) Google Scholar). In this respect, it is particularly interesting that helix VIII contains Glu-269, a residue that is essential for transport and interacts with another essential residue, His-322 (helix X), while helix VII contains Asp-237 and Asp-240 which interact with Lys-358 (helix XI) and Lys-319 (helix X), respectively (Kaback et al., 1994). Since helices VII and VIII interact with helix X which contains Glu-325 and mAb 4B1 mimics the effect of mutations at this position, torsional effects on either of these helices may alter the pKa of one or more residues in helices VII and/or VIII in such a manner as to increase the pKa of Glu-325, thereby limiting deprotonation of the permease at the surface of the membrane (Carrasco et al., 1986, 1989; Sun et al., 1996). Bogdanov and Dowhan(1995) postulated that lactose permease in PE-deficient membranes is unable to release a H+ on the inner surface of the membrane. Binding of mAb 4B1 also markedly alters the reactivity of a site-specific Cys replacement of Val-331 (helix X), as well as the fluorescence of this mutant after labeling the Cys with 2-(4′-maleimidylanilino)naphthalene-6-sulfonic acid (Sun et al., 1996). Taken together, the data are consistent with a role for PE in either the folding of helices VII and VIII or their packing within the bilayer. The observation that sufficient conformational memory remains in the permease after removal of PE and renaturation on a solid support to reform the 4B1 epitope indicates that PE does not act per se to maintain the conformation within L(VII/VIII). Rather, PE plays a role in the folding of either the epitope itself or helices VII and VIII which may determine the conformation of the epitope. Further support for this conclusion comes from the ability of PE to direct the formation of the epitope during renaturation from SDS of permease originally assembled in the absence of PE. Therefore, PE functions as do protein molecular chaperones in guiding the folding pathway which is a new and novel role for a phospholipid. What are the special properties of PE which may be related to its specific role in determining protein conformation? PE, unlike PC, has a strong tendency to form nonbilayer structures (Thurmond et al., 23.Thurmond R.L. Dodd S.W. Brown M.F. Biophys. J. 1991; 59: 108-113Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar), and, with its small head group, PE may interact at the interface between phospholipid and protein domains or intercalate within the packed helical structure of membrane proteins; helix VIII contains a region of low information content that has been postulated to be in contact with phospholipids (Hinkle et al., 14.Hinkle P.C. Hinkle P.V. Kaback H.R. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 10989-10994Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). PE (as well as PC) also exhibits a dipole moment over the ionic head group which can respond to membrane potential (Seelig, 19.Seelig J. Wirtz K.W.A. Parker L. Evangelopoulos J.Å. Changeues J.P. New Developments in Lipid-Protein Interactions and Receptor Functions. Plenum Press, London1993: 441-448Google Scholar). Positive charges have been postulated to interaction with π electrons of aromatic side chains of amino acids (Dougherty, 9.Dougherty D.S. Science. 1996; 271: 163-168Crossref PubMed Scopus (2357) Google Scholar). Not only are two Phe residues part of the determinant recognized by mAb 4B1, but the sequence in the region of L(VII/VIII), which is conserved among several other secondary transporters (Frillingos et al., 12.Frillingos S. Sahin-Tóth M. Persson B. Kaback H.R. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 8074-8081Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar), contains 6 Phe residues. Therefore, head group size and electrical properties of PE coupled with the ability to assume nonbilayer structures may combine to influence the final helix structure and packing of the permease and ultimately its function. In conclusion, the use of monoclonal antibodies in an Eastern-Western blot analysis of other membrane proteins may reveal additional examples of phospholipid-dependent organization of protein structure, especially for those proteins that require the addition of lipids to regain function. Direct assay of enzyme activity after transferring proteins to a solid support in an Eastern-Western blot may prove to be a useful screening technique to survey the role of specific lipids in protein function. The method described here could have broad application for the study of renaturation of proteins from SDS in the presence of either surface-bound ligands or ligands introduced into the electroblotting buffers. Certainly the realization that specific phospholipids can determine the folding pathway of a protein should be taken into account in designing experiments aimed at understanding the mechanism for assembling proteins into membranes. We thank Drs. Finn Wold and John DeMoss for their thoughtful comments. Phil Heacock was also very helpful by first finding references that described methods for applying lipids to nitrocellulose which was instrumental in developing the Eastern-Western blot procedure.

The cardiac Na+/Ca2+ exchanger (NCX1) plays a major role in the extrusion of Ca2+ from cardiomyocytes. We studied the role of protein phosphorylation in the regulation of cardiac NCX1 using CCL39 stably overexpressing the canine cardiac NCX1 and rat neonatal cardiomyocytes. In both cell types, the NCX1 protein immunoprecipitated with a chicken anti-NCX1 antibody exhibited a significant basal phosphorylation that was further enhanced by treatment with endothelin-1, acidic fibroblast growth factor, phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate, or okadaic acid. In contrast, calphostin C, K252a, or EGTA inhibited the phosphorylation. The phosphorylation occurred on two major tryptic phosphopeptides (P1 and P2) exclusively on serine residues. Evidence is presented suggesting that P2 was derived from an N-terminal half (amino acids 240-475) of the central cytoplasmic domain of NCX1 and was phosphorylated directly by protein kinase C (PKC). The agents that increased NCX1 phosphorylation significantly enhanced both the forward and reverse modes of Na+/Ca2+ exchange. This exchange activation exhibited a very good correlation with the NCX1 phosphorylation. In NCX1-transfected cells, PKC down-regulation following prolonged exposure to phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate abolished the acidic fibroblast growth factor-induced activation of exchange activity. On the other hand, cell ATP depletion reduced the exchange activity and abolished the effects of the above agents on exchange activity. These results indicate that the cardiac NCX1 is up-regulated by PKC-catalyzed phosphorylation. The cardiac NCX1 thus could play an important role in the previously reported negative inotropic actions of phorbol esters and other PKC-activating agents. Signal-dependent activation of the transcription factor NF-κB is dominantly regulated by degradation of IκB-α protein. However, the signaling pathways that lead to the degradation are not clear. Here we report that mitogen-activated protein kinase/extracellular signal-regulated kinase kinase (MEK) kinase, an activator of stress-activated protein kinases/jun kinase-1 (SAPKs/JNK1), is involved in such signaling pathways. The transient overexpression of MEK kinase in NIH3T3 fibroblasts activates κB-CAT reporter expression in a synergistic manner with TNFα stimulation. In contrast, overexpression of kinase-negative MEK kinase suppresses TNFα-induced reporter expression. The overexpression of MEK kinase suppresses the inhibitory activity of co-transfected IκB-α on the κB-CAT or human immunodeficiency virus-long terminal repeat-luciferase reporter expression and causes the simultaneous disappearance of the overexpressed IκB-α. The disappearance of exogenous IκB-α by the overexpression of MEK kinase is prevented by calpain inhibitor-I, an inhibitor of IκB-α degradation. These results suggest that MEK kinase is a signal mediator involved in TNFα-induced NF-κB activation and that the activation of NF-κB by MEK kinase is regulated through the degradation of IκB-α. Ca2+ mobilization from intracellular stores constitutes an important mechanism for generating cytoplasmic Ca2+ signals. Inositol trisphosphate (InsP3) and ryanodine receptors are the two families of intracellular Ca2+ release channels that have been identified, which may be regulated by separate intracellular messengers, InsP3 and cyclic adenosine 5′-diphosphate ribose, respectively. A third molecule, nicotinic acid adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NAADP), has recently been recognized as a potent Ca2+ releasing agent in sea urchin eggs and microsomes. We now report that non-releasing concentrations of NAADP fully and irreversibly inactivate the NAADP-sensitive Ca2+ release mechanism. This phenomenon occurred both in intact sea urchin eggs and in homogenates and is not shared by either InsP3 or cyclic adenosine 5′-diphosphate ribose. The novel properties of this Ca2+ release mechanism, giving a one-shot Ca2+ release, may be suited to irreversible cellular events. Ca2+ mobilization from intracellular stores constitutes an important mechanism for generating cytoplasmic Ca2+ signals. We now report that non-releasing concentrations of NAADP fully and irreversibly inactivate the NAADP-sensitive Ca2+ release mechanism. This phenomenon occurred both in intact sea urchin eggs and in homogenates and is not shared by either InsP3 or cyclic adenosine 5′-diphosphate ribose. The novel properties of this Ca2+ release mechanism, giving a one-shot Ca2+ release, may be suited to irreversible cellular events.

Rabbit reticulocyte lysate contains a multiprotein system that assembles steroid receptors into a heterocomplex with hsp90. In the case of the glucocorticoid receptor (GR), the receptor must be bound to hsp90 to bind steroid, and assembly of the GR·hsp90 complex restores the hormone binding domain of the receptor to the steroid binding conformation. Using both direct assay of heterocomplex assembly by Western blotting and indirect assay of assembly by steroid binding, it has previously been determined that the assembly system is both ATP/Mg2+-dependent and K+-dependent and that hsp70 and an acidic 23-kDa protein (p23) are required to form a functional GR·hsp90 complex. It is also thought that a 60-kDa protein (p60) may be required for progesterone receptor·hsp90 heterocomplex assembly, but a complete heterocomplex assembly system has never been reconstituted from individual components. In this work, we separate the proteins of rabbit reticulocyte lysate into three fractions by DEAE chromatography and then reconstitute the GR·hsp90 heterocomplex assembly system in a manner that requires the presence of each fraction. Fraction A contains most of the hsp70 and all of the p60 in lysate, and elimination of p60 by immunoadsorption inactivates this fraction, with bioactivity being restored by the addition of bacterially expressed human p60. The activity of fraction A is replaced by a combination of highly purified rabbit hsp70 and lysate from p60-expressing bacteria. Fraction B contains hsp90, and its activity is replaced by purified rabbit hsp90. Fraction C contains p23, and its activity is replaced in the recombined system by highly purified bacterially expressed human p23. A minimal GR·hsp90 heterocomplex assembly system was reconstituted with purified rabbit hsp70 and hsp90 and bacterially expressed human p23 and p60. This reports the first reconstitution of this apparently ubiquitous protein folding/heterocomplex assembly system. Celis J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 8485-8491Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) to be up-regulated by viral transformation, and it is a homolog of the nonessential yeast heat shock protein, Sti1 (18Nicolet C.M. Craig E.A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 3638-3646Crossref PubMed Scopus (199) Google Scholar). It is established that p60, hsp90, and hsp70 interact with each other (19Smith D.F. Sullivan W.P. Marion T.N. Zaitsu K. Madden B. McCormick D.J. Toft D.O. Mol. Cell. The immune adsorption of hsp90 from reticulocyte lysate and other cell extracts copurifies several proteins, including hsp70, p60, p23, and the immunophilins FKBP52/hsp56 (also called p59) and CyP-40 (19Smith D.F. Sullivan W.P. Marion T.N. Zaitsu K. Madden B. McCormick D.J. Toft D.O. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 869-876Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar, 20Sanchez E.R. Faber L.E. Henzel W.T. Pratt W.B. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 5145-5152Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar, 21Perdew G.H. Whitelaw M.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 6708-6713Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The immunoadsorbed hsp90 with its coimmunoadsorbed proteins contains all the components of reticulocyte lysate required to reassociate the GR with hsp90 and to restore the receptor to its steroid binding state (22Hutchison K.A. Dittmar K.D. Pratt W.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 27894-27899Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The immunophilin components of this foldosome machinery are not required for GR·hsp90 heterocomplex assembly (23Owens-Grillo J.K. Hoffmann K. Hutchison K.A. Yem A.W. Deibel M.R. Handschumacher R.E. Pratt W.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 20479-20484Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar), but a loosely associated component that is easily washed away is required to form a functional (i.e. steroid binding) GR·hsp90 complex (22Hutchison K.A. Dittmar K.D. Pratt W.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 27894-27899Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This weakly bound component has been identified as p23 (15Hutchison K.A. Stancato L.F. Owens-Grillo J.K. Johnson J.L. Krishna P. Toft D.O. Pratt W.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 18841-18847Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). It is thought that the core complex for receptor heterocomplex assembly may be the hsp90·p60·hsp70 unit and that p60 dissociates after hsp70 and hsp90 bind to the receptor, with p23 becoming tightly bound to the receptor heterocomplex at that time. To define the mechanism of heterocomplex assembly in greater detail, the system must first be reconstituted from purified components. In this work, we have separated rabbit reticulocyte lysate into three fractions that contain the four identified components of the heterocomplex assembly system. When the fraction containing hsp70 and p60 is reconstituted with two other fractions containing hsp90 and p23, respectively, the heterocomplex assembly activity of reticulocyte lysate is reconstituted. Substitution of the reticulocyte lysate fractions with purified rabbit hsp90 and hsp70 and bacterially expressed human p23 and p60 yields a system that assembles a GR·hsp90 complex with steroid binding activity. Although it is likely that other proteins (e.g. rDnaJ, p48) are required for optimal heterocomplex assembly in intact cells, this work identifies a minimal system for receptor heterocomplex assembly under cell-free conditions.
